awd_titl_txt: CNH:  Impacts of Ecosystem Service Payments in Coupled Natural and Human Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Payments for ecosystem services are incentives paid to users of natural resources to reduce their use of these resources and the accompanying stresses and disturbances to the natural systems that provide the resources. Although some systems of payments have been in place for over two decades, the success of payments in maintaining both ecosystems and human well-being has not been critically assessed.  This project will study the system of payments in Fanjingshan National Nature Reserve in China, the habitat of the endangered Guizhou golden monkey, Rhinopithecus brelichi.  To assess effects on the ecosystem, researchers will use remote sensing to measure change in forest cover and use camera trapping to measure which forest areas are serving as habitat for golden monkeys.  To assess effects on the local people, researchers will combine existing census data with extensive household surveys and participatory mapping.  Results will show how human populations, attachment to the land, decisions, and livelihoods have changed since payments began, how the quality of the forest has changed, and how these changes in the human and the natural systems depend on each other and are likely to go on in the future.  These findings will assess how well payments for ecosystem services have succeeded at Fanjingshan, show how to assess other systems of payments, and suggest how to improve the effectiveness of payments.

The project will help test and hone an important tool for conservation.  Previous work suggests that the benefits of payment programs to biological conservation and local populations are usually not sustained once payments end, because participants tend to return to their behaviors before the program.  This project will specifically examine this issue as part of its general aim to enhance ability to plan, design, and implement payment programs, and thus to increase the effectiveness of tax dollars in protecting our environment. The research will educate K-12 students and teachers in both the United States and China through mentoring and curriculum development, feed into the development of curricula for university students, and train future academic leaders in multiple disciplines. The project will reach out to local indigenous populations, managers, policy-makers and the general public, increasing understanding of how payment programs work and leading to improvements in conservation awareness, conservation planning and design, and policy implementation.  In addition to regular presentations and publications, a movie that documents the multidisciplinary nature of the project and a comprehensive website will be developed to reach stakeholders at local to global scales. All these efforts will contribute to increasing understanding about how to conserve endangered species and associated ecosystems.

por.por_cntn:
Research Question 1: What measurable environmental changes have taken place after implementing the PES programs (PES-induced environmental changes)? 

The study substantially improves our understanding of environmental responses to human disturbances or policies such as payments for ecosystem service (PES). Through this project, we measured canopy fractional cover using an up-looking camera system in the field, estimated forest coverage with Landsat images with an innovative illumination stratification strategy, generated forest vegetation type and land use maps, and map land cover changes between 1989 and 2016 for FNNR and its surrounding area, including PES land. Maps products such as canopy fractional cover maps and land cover and land use maps revealed that most of the environmental changes in FNNR are associated with natural hazard such as landslides, tourism and transportation development, and afforestation through PES. We also found while forest cover may be a good proxy for some metrics of forest structure, it does not serve as a robust proxy for many biodiversity parameters. These findings highlight the need for and importance of robust and representative indicators or proxy variables for ecological effects of PES programs on compositional and structural diversity. We demonstrate PES can provide modest improvements in species biodiversity, but changes in program implementation are warranted to improve the return on investment of PES programs to support conservation of biodiversity and biodiversity-related ecosystem services.

Research Question 2: What changes have arisen in human livelihoods, demography, and their interrelationships following PES implementation? And how are these changes feeding back on the PES program (Understand human systems)?

This study paves the way for an innovative coupled human and natural systems (CHANS) methodology from a complex systems perspective. For instance, the findings about the lack of coordination among PES programs (including the cancelation of each other’s benefits) will likely stimulate the PES planners and practitioners rethink and redevelop their programs. Also intriguingly, the third phase of China’s Grain to Green Program (GTGP) is being implemented, and we will be able to develop and polish more models or theories about the effectiveness of PES programs. For example, our results about effects of GTGP on migration are consistent with government policy goals of reforestation and stimulating changes in farmer livelihoods including more out-migration to urban areas, leading in many cases to substantial remittances to origin households.

Research Question 3: How does the coupled system evolve over space and time as humans and the environment interact with one another and with PES (Coupled natural human systems)? 

Our project is expanding the theory of the multiphasic response to make it a powerful tool for explaining human behaviors in CNH systems. Ecosystem services can contribute to reducing local people’s costs of conservation. However, exploitation of ecosystem services often results in ecosystem degradation. Although fuelwood collection, which is one of the key drivers of deforestation, can be prevented through increased conservation payments, allowing fuelwood collection under forest management that fulfills conservation goals of the reserve can substantially reduce the costs of conservation investment in PES. Our innovative use of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) may pave a new way for detecting and monitoring human activities over large spatial and temporal scales.

Education and Outreach

Our team has been enthusiastic in disseminating our models, data, and results to various communities. We conducted several workshops for about 40 K-12 teachers in San Diego and Guizhou Province (Jiangkou). In Jiangkou Elementary school, China, our project team met with 6 teachers and trained them how to use technology in teaching. In San Diego area, teachers are from middle and high schools, teaching a variety of subjects: math, science, English, social studies, environmental science, etc.

We developed an online, cloud-based Google Earth Engine tool to access Landsat image archive and generate vegetation type/land use maps for a user specified time period. This cloud-based tool enables FNNR staff to identify land cover changes, and also generate up-to-date land use maps in the future for long term land change monitoring. Also a dual-language (English and Chinese), the Cyber PES Center at http://complexities.org/pes, was finalized, which include many PES related resources including our papers and findings.

Dr. Li An traveled to FNNR in December 2016 and May 2017. Our major findings were conveyed to reserve managers. Consequently, the FNNR leaders are very enthusiastic about these findings, and expect to strengthen our collaboration. Dr. Li An was included as editorial board of  a book series about  research achievements and findings about Fanjingshan National Nature Reserve” recently published, which include  Fanjingshan  Moss (Yuanxin  Xiong  and Lei Shi, 2014; Guizhou Science and Technology Press), China’s Fanjingshan Fungi (Xingliang Wu et al., 2014;  China  Science  and  Technology  Press); Chinese  Medicinal  Herbs  in  Fanjingshan (Chuandong Yang,  Lei  Shi,  and Xiaoping  Lei, 2016;  Guizhou  Science  and  Technology Press); Birds  at  Fanjingshan (Zhongfan Kuang, Kefeng Niu, 2017; Guizhou Science and Technology Press).
